free_text.Learning outcomes: The statistical modelling of rare events, such as stock market crashes, storms and catastrophic structural failures, is increasingly seen to be important. For example, the most destructive effects of climatic change are likely to be due to changes in extreme events, and events in the financial markets are also often modelled using methods from extreme-value statistics. This course will describe the special models and methods that are relevant to the analysis of such data, including the mathematical bases, statistical tools, and practical applications.
free_text.Content: [li] [b]Mathematical bases[/b]: behaviour of maxima and threshold exceedances in large samples, both for independent and dependent data.[br/][br/][li] [b]Statistical methods[/b]: modelling using the GEV and GP distributions, for independent and dependent data. Non-stationarity. Extremal coefficients. Multivariate data. Likelihood and Bayesian inference. Geostatistics of extremes.[br/][br/][li] [b]Applications[/b]: environmental, financial, and engineering applications. Use of R for extremal modelling.
free_text.Type of teaching: Ex cathedra lecture and exercises in the classroom
